properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A weather system moving through central Manitoba will bring an additional 2 to 4 cm of snow tonight for storm totals of 15 to 25 cm. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system will bring 10 to 20 millimetres of rain between Monday evening and Tuesday evening over Southern and Central Quebec. Further north, snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres are possible from Monday morning to Tuesday evening in a corridor stretching from Abitibi towards Chaleur Bay. Snow accompanied by moderate winds may reduce visibilities locally in blowing snow. Freezing rain is likely in the vicinity of the snow-to-rain transition area. A more important episode of freezing rain is also likely for regions of the St. Lawrence Valley between Montreal and Quebec City on Tuesday. The Quebec City Area will likely be the most affected region. Travel could be difficult, especially at rush hour Tuesday morning. There is still much uncertainty about the track of this system and thus about the type and amount of precipitation expected. Please stay tuned for future forecasts. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-09T18:59:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-09T03:00:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3688326632.2020

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwest winds of 40 gusting 60 km/h combined with bitterly cold air is giving blowing snow conditions with wind chill values near -55 this morning. The blowing snow conditions and extreme wind chill values will slowly moderate as the winds diminish later this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-09T16:59:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-09T08:14:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1613857109.2020
Area: Hall Beach
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions continue for Coral Harbour this morning. An intense low pressure system east of Baffin Island and a strong ridge of high pressure to the west combine to give northwest winds sustained at 40 km/h and low visibilities in blowing snow. As the ridge slowly builds in, wind speeds should ease through the morning hours and the blowing snow will taper off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-09T16:59:50-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-09T08:09:50-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2773870815.2020
Area: Coral Harbour

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged period of snow and freezing rain Tuesday into Wednesday morning. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm for central to northern areas. Trace to 5 cm for southern areas. Locations: most of New Brunswick except for the Fundy coast. Time span: Tonight into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Periods of snow today over central and northern New Brunswick will taper off this afternoon but then pick up in intensify early Tuesday morning before ending on Wednesday morning. A prolonged period of freezing rain is possible for parts of southern and central New Brunswick, especially along the Saint John river Valley Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-09T23:45:21-00:00
